A copy of the most recent RMP Submit form for the facility is incorporated in Appendix B of this RMP.

Executive Summary

1.1	Discussion
If a facility handles, manufactures, uses in a process or stores any of the toxic or flammable substances listed in 40 CFR §68.130 above the specified threshold quantities, the facility is required to develop and implement a Risk Management Plan.  The Chemical Accident Prevention rule was issued and is administered by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). This rule, "Chemical Accident Prevention (CAP) Provisions" (Part 68 of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR)), applies to a wide variety of facilities that handle, manufacture, store or use toxic and/or flammable substances.
The Global Erie Boulevard Terminal has the capacity to store up to 2.26 million pounds of LPG at their distribution facility located at 51 Erie Boulevard in Albany, New York. Global is required to address requirements of the CAP regulations because they exceed the 10,000 pound LPG threshold outside of internal fuel and/or retail sales.  The terminal is a wholesale distributor of LPG, and is not subject to the exemptions extended to propane facilities in accordance with the Chemical Safety Information, Site Security and Fuels Regulatory Relief Act of 2000.
Global operates the Albany facility owned by the Canadian Pacific Railway, and provides wholesale LPG distribution to the local home heating, industrial, and commercial markets. The two regulated substances stored and distributed are propane and butane (both referred in this document as LPG). The LPG is brought into the Albany facility by railcar, offloaded into six (6) 105,000 gallon tanks in a subterranean mounded tank farm. A maximum of 85% of capacity is stored in these tanks that are connected by manifold fixed piping systems. 
Global is also subject to the Process Safety Management (PSM) standard under the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) regulation 29 CFR 1910.119. Global Erie Blvd. Terminal is a CAP Program 3 facility, and EPA CAP Program 3 requirements f

ulfill OSHA PSM requirements.    
The Risk Management Plan contains the Policies and Procedures used at Global to assure continued compliance with the EPA CAP and OSHA PSM regulations and is considered an integrated management system.  Most of the documents that are part of the Risk Management Plan follow a standard format that includes the purpose, organization, responsibilities and authorities, as well as general step-by-step instructions.  
Most procedures contain information on document control and filing.  Typically, documents are periodically revised through the procedures outlined in Section 9 - Management of Change.  
Employees are required to review relevant elements of the Risk Management Plan's policies and procedures.  The manual is available on-site for employee review.  Recommendations to improve this document's accuracy or effectiveness in assuring employee, visitor and contractor safety can be directed to the Terminal Manager. 
The goal of the Risk Management Plan is to prevent accidental releases of substances that can cause serious harm to the public and the environment from short-term exposures and to mitigate the severity of releases that do occur. The 1990 Amendments to the Clean Air Act (CAA) required EPA to issue a rule specifying the type of actions to be taken by facilities to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals into the atmosphere and to reduce their potential impact on the public and the environment. 
The phrase "Risk Management Plan" refers to this document as well as the registration information submitted to EPA.  In general, the EPA CAP regulations require covered facilities to develop and implement a Risk Management Plan and maintain documentation required by the plan on site.  The Risk Management Plan includes an analysis of the potential offsite consequences of an accidental release, a five-year accident history, a release prevention program and an emergency response program.
Covered facilities also must su

bmit registration information (RMP Submit) to EPA no later than June 21, 1999 or the date on which the facility first has more than a threshold quantity in use or stored at the site, whichever is later.  Covered facilities are also required to re-submit their Risk Management Plans every five years.  The RMP Submit provides an electronic summary of the facility's Risk Management Plan.
Covered facilities also must continue to implement the management practices documented in this plan and update their plans periodically or when processes change, as required by the rule.

1.1.1	Management System
The implementation and management responsibilities for the Plan must be clearly defined.  This section discusses various duties that must be addressed in order to fulfill the intent of the Plan.  This section also describes the employee responsibilities associated with each duty.  

1.1.2	Hazard Assessment
A component of the Risk Management Plan is the assessment of impacts associated with the accidental release of regulated substances.  This section evaluates both the worst-case release as well as alternative releases that are specific to the site.
The analysis focused on the impact to neighboring areas called receptors.  Receptors include residences, schools, parks, prisons, commercial buildings, etc.  Graphic as well as tabulated exhibits help to define the impact of accidental releases.
Based on guidelines provided by EPA in the 2009 RMP Submit Instruction Manual, release scenario information is not provided in this Executive Summary.
 
1.1.3	Process Safety Information
Process Safety Information (PSI) is a repository for information related to the safety of a process.  Three major subjects addressed in this section are:

¿	The hazards of the chemicals and the process (physical properties, toxicity and exposure limits, fire and explosion characteristics, reactivity data, thermal and chemical stability, corrosivity data).
¿	The process technology (process

chemistry, process flow diagrams, safe operating limits, maximum intended inventories, consequences of deviation).
¿	Equipment information (piping and instrumentation diagrams, material and energy balances, safety systems involved, materials of construction, electrical classification, relief system design and design basis, ventilation system design and design basis, design codes and standards employed).  This information is used as a reference during Process Hazards Analyses.
Documentation is found primarily in the Safety Data Sheets (SDS), the Risk Management Plan and the Process Safety Information files.
The LPG distribution system (the "covered process") was designed in accordance with recognized engineering standards at the time of construction and will be incorporated, as appropriate, for any subsequent renovations to the system in accordance with Management of Change procedures.  Documentation regarding recognized engineering standards can be found in the terminal design documents and process safety information files.  The facility follows documented procedures for inspection and maintenance at the terminal as documented in the Operations and Maintenance Manual.

1.1.4	Process Hazard Analysis
Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) is a systematic approach toward evaluating the safety of a process.  PHAs must address the hazards of a process, previous incidents having potential for serious consequences, engineering and administrative controls, facility siting, human factors and an evaluation of the range of exposures if controls fail.  If there is more than one process, a schedule for completing PHAs must be formulated and based on the extent of process hazards, the number of potentially affected employees, the age of the process and the operating history of the process.  PHAs must follow a standard methodology, such as a What If/Checklist Analysis and be performed by a cross-functional team with at least one person who is familiar with the process, at least once

every five years.  A system for addressing, resolving, documenting and communicating all recommendations in a prompt manner must also be in place.
In accordance with the EPA's guidance document titled "Risk Management Program Guidance Document for Propane Storage Facilities", published in 2009, a Fire Safety Analysis (FSA) per National Fire Protection Association 58 fulfills the PHA. The FSA will be performed every 5 years or after a major change to the covered process, per regulatory requirements.
Typical documentation should include information on how FSA studies were prioritized, employee briefings on the FSAs, a copy of each FSA file index and evidence of how FSA recommendations were completed.  These FSA files include the pertinent process safety information.
The most recent FSA was conducted in March of 2013 and completed upon commissioning of the facility. Included were representatives from Global Companies, Tighe & Bond, Duck Harbor Energy, and various contract firms which designed the LPG system, designed the LPG system controls and service the LPG handling system.  

1.1.5	Operating Procedures
Operating procedures are instructions that outline how to safely operate a process consistent with Process Safety Information.  They must be appropriate, clear, consistent and well communicated.  Procedures must address steps for each operating phase (initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operation, normal shutdown, startup after a turnaround), operating limits (consequences of deviation, steps to correct or avoid) and safety and health considerations (properties/hazards of chemicals, precautions to avoid exposure, control measures in the event contact occurs, quality control, inventory control, special or unique hazards, safety systems & their function).  Procedures must be accessible and certified to be correct at least annually.  Safe work procedures must exist for hot work, lockout/tagout, confined space ent

ry, opening process equipment/piping and controlling entry to storage and distribution areas, for both employees and contractors.
Typical documentation should include evidence that employees had input to the content and format of Operating Instructions, an index of all Operating Instructions, completed Confined Space Entry permits, completed Lockout/Tagout Program audit forms, etc.  Copies of the Operating Instructions are kept in the Operating Procedure File.
Duck Harbor Energy developed the initial Standard Operating Procedures for the terminal based on the Propane Education & Research Council (PERC) Operations & Maintenance Manual.  These procedures are documented in the Operations and Maintenance Plan and are readily available to terminal operators.  Operators at the facility reviewed and commented on draft procedures developed by Duck Harbor Energy, and Tighe & Bond provided an overview of the SOPs to ensure compliance with environmental, health, and safety regulations.  The Operators' comments are included in the final procedures incorporated into the Risk Management Plan. These documents are located in the Operator's Room. 
Operating procedures are reviewed and certified on an annual basis by Global.  Substantive changes to the procedures are noted in a controlled manner.  If substantial changes to the LPG system require revision to the operating procedures, such changes are tracked through the Management of Change process.

1.1.6	Employee Training Program
Initial training must be provided for employees involved with CAP covered processes that cover an overview of the process, specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations including shutdown and other safe work procedures that may be applicable.  For existing employees, the employer must document that operators have the required knowledge in lieu of initial training.  Refresher training must be provided periodically that covers understanding and adherence to current operating procedures.  Reco

rds must be kept that verify that an employee has received and understood the training; these records must include employee identification, date of training and method of verification.
Documentation is found primarily in the Training Files.  This file should contain evidence that employees had input into retraining frequency and other aspects of the training program.
The Terminal Manager and Terminal Operators are provided with initial and required refresher training in accordance with the National Propane Gas Association Certified Employee Training Program (CETP).  Training includes both classroom and hands-on training performed by qualified personnel.  NPGA administers a standardized testing program for CETP.
Emergency preparedness and response training is provided to the Terminal Manager / Operators through the CETP and initial / annual training in accordance with OSHA Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) requirements.  Personnel are trained to act in a defensive manner in the event of a LPG release, consistent with the requirements in the Emergency Response Action Plan.

1.1.7	Mechanical Integrity Program
Written procedures have been developed for maintaining the ongoing integrity of process equipment.  Mechanical Integrity (MI) applies to pressure vessels and storage tanks; piping systems and their components; relief and vent systems and associated devices; emergency shutdown systems; controls (sensors, alarms, interlocks); and pumps.  Mechanical integrity activities include routine site inspections, facility tours, preventative maintenance and equipment replacement practices.
The terminal Operations and Maintenance Manual documents  require maintenance practices.  This manual is readily available to Terminal Operators.  The O&M manual was developed by a competent expert in LPG facility design and operations and in consultation with Global personnel.  
The Terminal Manager is responsible for reviewing and tracking mechanical inte

grity activities, in accordance with the O&M manual on a regular basis.  The Terminal Manager also maintains documents validating that the required mechanical integrity activities were conducted.

1.1.8	Management of Change
Global has a system to properly manage changes to the covered process, which includes changes that are not otherwise replacement "in-kind".  The Management of Change (MOC) form must include the technical basis for the change; impact of the change on employee safety & health; modifications to operating procedures; modifications to process safety information; time period involved; and authorization requirements.  Employees and contractors must be informed of the change prior to implementation.
MOC is a documented process to ensure that changes to the covered process are addressed comprehensively through a checklist maintained by the Terminal Manager.  Process changes are authorized through the MOC form and tracked to ensure that the necessary safety aspects of the change are addressed.  Typical documentation includes MOC worksheets (including employee review sheets) and related reference materials.  
 
1.1.9	Pre-Startup Safety Review
The Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSR) is a review of new or significantly modified processes prior to introducing the regulated substance.  The review includes confirmation that construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications; that safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place; that the action items have been addressed; and that training of employees is complete.
A PSR is typically a combination of management system tools documented in the RMP and may include:

¿	Management of Change
¿	Facility startup checklist (appended to MOC form)
¿	Revised / Modified Process Hazard Analysis
¿	Facility commissioning review

Due to the extensive nature of the project, the pre-startup review process is typically managed by a dedicated Project Manager or by the Terminal

Manager, as needed.  Extensive involvement by the engineer responsible for the system design is also common.
Typical documentation includes the records listed above, plus records validating that the required activities were completed.  The review documentation is filed in the Terminal Manager's office.  Records are maintained for the life of the process.

1.1.10 Compliance Audits
Global has a process for regular internal compliance audits in accordance with the requirements in 40 CFR 68.79.  Internal audits are required, by regulation, at least every 3 years.  Compliance audits are conducted by competent personnel with knowledge of the regulatory requirements subject to evaluation and rudimentary knowledge of the process.
A documented internal audit report is generated following the audit.  Any recommendations from the audit are tracked until completed by the Terminal Manager.  The audit report is maintained on file (at least two prior reports) as well as documented evidence of corrective action.

1.1.11 Incident Investigation
A thorough investigation of any incident that could or resulted in an emergency release of highly hazardous chemicals must take place within 48 hours of the incident.  This investigation must identify the chain of events and causes of the incident and include corrective measures that can be developed and implemented.  Global has an incident investigation program as part of the RMP.  The Terminal Manager is responsible for reviewing and approving investigation reports.  The Terminal Manager is also responsible for tracking recommendations from the incident reports to completion.
Incident investigation reports are retained for the life of the process and are review as part of the 5-year system-wide process hazard analysis.

1.1.12 Employee Participation
This Section outlines how employees participate in the development of the facility's Risk Management Plan.  Employee participation in this program is achieved through the following a

ctivities:

¿	Review and comment on the Risk Management Plan
¿	Review and comment on operating procedures
¿	Participation in incident investigation teams
¿	Participation in process hazard analysis
¿	Participation in pre-startup or management of change reviews
¿	Other RMP related project as directed by the Terminal Manager

1.1.13 Hot Work Permit
This permit system is for all work involving flames, heat or sparks or any other activity which has the potential to cause a fire outside of designated areas for that purpose.  It includes hot work operations (e.g., welding, cutting, etc.) conducted on or near a covered process as described in the operating procedures.  Due to the highly flammable nature of the regulated substance, significant controls are employed prior to, during and following hot work near the covered process.  
Requirements include the completion and adherence to permit conditions by all those involved in the hot work.  Hot work requirements are communicated to employees and contractors through routine training.  The permit satisfies the requirements of OSHA 29 CFR 1910.252(a), fire prevention and protection.  The permit must be kept on file while hot work proceeds.

1.1.14 Contractor Safety
Employers must inform contractors of known potential fire, explosion or toxic release hazards; explain applicable provisions of the emergency action plan; develop/implement safe work practices that control the presence, entrance and exit of contract employees in covered LPG storage and distribution areas; periodically evaluate contractor safety performance.  This applies to contractors working in or around CAP covered processes who perform maintenance or repairs, help with facility turnarounds or major renovations or do specialty work (e.g., chemical suppliers, instrumentation service contractors).  Employers must obtain and evaluate contractor safety performance and programs.
Typical documentation should include criteria for evaluating contractor safe

ty programs, how the criteria were applied, any on-site monitoring performed while contractors were working and actions taken when contractor deficiencies were found.
The RMP has a contractor evaluation process, which include submittal and completion of pre-qualification evaluation forms.  Contractor evaluation forms were sent to Mackey Electric, Petro-Chem Mechanical Services, and Hiltz Propane Systems.  Completed evaluation forms and other information can be found in the Terminal Manager records..
 
The RMP also has a safe work permit system, which is used to review and address safety elements of the contractors work.  The safe work permit is reviewed and completed by the contractor and Global prior to beginning the work on the covered process.  The safe work permit is valid for the duration of the project and is maintained by the Terminal Manager for 3 years as demonstration of compliance.
Designated Global personnel will periodically review contractor safety practices when on-site to evaluate safety performance.  

1.1.15 Emergency Response Program
An emergency action plan is required that satisfies the requirements of EPA 40 CFR 68 Subpart E, OSHA 29 CFR 1910.38 and 29 CFR 1910.120.  The plan must include procedures for handling releases of the regulated substance.  Employees must be aware of the plan and trained in specific procedures.  The regulations require a written plan that addresses emergency escape procedures; procedures for employees who remain to operate critical equipment; procedures to account for all personnel; rescue and medical duties; means of reporting emergencies; and a list of persons or departments who can answer any questions.  Further, the regulations require an alarm system; an evacuation procedure; and training for new employees and for employees who are affected by any changes to the plan.
Global has an Emergency Response Action Plan for the facility which has been coordinated with the Local Emergency Planning Commission

and the Albany Fire Department.  Representatives at Global have met with the Albany Fire Department to plan and coordinate actions in the unlikely event of an LPG release.  Global hosts a facility tour with the fire department on a periodic basis to identify critical controls and hazards to firefighters.
Global also maintains a hazardous chemical emergency response team to address chemical spills and releases at the facility.  The team has been provided with initial training in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.120 and is provided with refresher training annually.  

1.2	RMP Submittal Form
The RMP Submittal form is an abbreviated questionnaire with information collected from this RMP.  The RMP Submittal form was developed using EPA's RMP*Submit CDX website.  While Global is required to adhere to the policies and procedures documented in this RMP, only the information required in RMP Submit is sent to EPA.
 
Covered facilities must prepare or update the RMP Submittal form when they are first subject to the Chemical Accident Prevention Rule and every five years thereafter.  The RMP Submittal form must be submitted to EPA more frequently under the following conditions.

¿	No later than three years after a newly regulated substance is first listed by EPA
¿	No later than the date on which a new regulated substance is first present in an already covered process above a threshold quantity
¿	No later than the date on which a regulated substance is first present above a threshold quantity in a new process
¿	Within one month of a change in emergency coordinators or contact information
¿	Within six months of a change that requires a revised Process Hazard Analysis or hazard review
¿	Within six months of a change that requires a revised offsite consequence analysis as provided in §68.36
¿	Within six months of a change that alters the Program level that applied to any covered process
